{{Infobox person | name = Jennifer Aaker | image = File:Dr. Jennifer Aaker (2013).jpg | image_size = 250px | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1967|1|15}} | birth_place = [[Palo Alto, California]], [[United States|US]] | residence = [[Lafayette, California|Lafayette]], [[California]] | occupation = [[Author]], [[Social psychologist]] | alma_mater = [[University of California, Berkeley]]
[[Stanford Graduate School of Business]] | boards = [[Brit + Co]]
[[California Casualty]]
Your Story
Accompani
Pixlee | spouse = [[Andy Smith (entrepreneur)|Andy Smith]] | website = http://faculty-gsb.stanford.edu/aaker/ }} '''Jennifer Aaker''' (born 1967, California) is an American social psychologist, author and General Atlantic Professor of Marketing at [[Stanford Graduate School of Business]]. Best known for her research on time, money and happiness,{{cite web|last=Cook|first=Nancy|title=The Corporate Pursuit of Happiness|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/1722637/corporate-pursuit-happiness|work=March, 2011|publisher=Fast Company|accessdate=19 June 2013}} Aaker also focuses on the transmission of ideas through social networks, the power of story in decision making, and how to build global brands across cultures.{{cite web|title=The Brainiacs: Most Influential Women In Technology|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/women-in-tech/2011/brainiacs/jennifer-aaker|work=2011|publisher=Fast Company|accessdate=4 June 2013}}{{cite web|title=Faculty Profile: Jennifer Aaker|url=http://faculty-gsb.stanford.edu/aaker/|publisher=Stanford Graduate School of Business|accessdate=6 June 2013}} She is the recipient of the Distinguished Scientific Achievement Award from the [[Society for Consumer Psychology]] and the Stanford Distinguished Teaching Award.{{cite web|title=Jennifer Aaker: Psychology Today |url=http://www.psychologytoday.com/experts/jennifer-aaker |work=2014 |publisher=Psychology Today |accessdate=27 February 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140306113958/http://www.psychologytoday.com/experts/jennifer-aaker |archivedate= 6 March 2014 |df= }} == Early life and education == Aaker was born in [[Palo Alto, California]], to Kay Aaker,{{cite web|last=Wake|first=Jennifer|title=The Gift of Time: Skilled Volunteers Found in Local Retirees|url=http://www.volunteereastbay.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/The_Gift_of_Time.pdf|work=April 15, 2009|publisher=La Morinda Weekly|accessdate=7 June 2013}} and [[David Aaker]], a professor and brand consultant.{{cite web|title=David A. Aaker, Author Profile|url=http://authors.simonandschuster.com/David-A-Aaker/1451364|publisher=Simon and Schuster|accessdate=7 June 2013}} Aaker attended the [[University of California, Berkeley]], where she studied under social psychologist [[Philip E. Tetlock]] and [[Nobel Prize]] winner [[Daniel Kahneman]], receiving a [[Bachelor of Arts]] in [[Psychology]] in 1989. In 1990, Aaker began postgraduate work at Stanford Graduate School of Business, earning a Ph.D. in marketing with a minor in psychology in 1995. Her dissertation on brand personality led to the publication of three academic papers in ''Journal of Marketing Research'' and ''Journal of Consumer Research'' and won several awards.{{cite web|title=Honors and Recognition |url=http://faculty.gsb.stanford.edu/aaker/documents/Aaker_Vita.pdf |work=2013 |publisher=Stanford University |accessdate=15 June 2013 }}{{dead link|date=April 2017|bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} == Career == Aaker began her academic career in 1995 as an assistant professor at the [[UCLA Anderson School of Management]]. In 1999, she returned to the Stanford Graduate School of Business as an assistant professor, was promoted to associate professor in 2001, and earned a full professorship in 2004. In 2005, Aaker was named General Atlantic Professor of Marketing.{{cite web|title=Aaker CV at Stanford Graduate School of Business |url=http://faculty-gsb.stanford.edu/aaker/documents/Aaker_Vita.pdf |work=January, 2013 |publisher=Stanford University |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130722150424/http://faculty-gsb.stanford.edu/aaker/documents/Aaker_Vita.pdf |archivedate=2013-07-22 |df= }} Her work has been published in scholarly journals in psychology and marketing and has been highlighted in ''[[The Economist]]'', ''[[The New York Times]]'', ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', ''[[The Washington Post]]'', ''[[Bloomberg Businessweek|BusinessWeek]]'', ''[[Forbes]],'' [[NPR]], ''[[CBS MoneyWatch]]'', ''[[Inc. (magazine)|Inc.]]'' and ''[[Science (journal)|Science]].'' She serves as an advisory board member for several private companies. As a social psychologist and marketer, Aaker began her research career by proposing a "Dimensions of Brand Personality" framework to describe and measure the "personality" of a brand, defined as the set of human characteristics associated with it. The five core dimensions are Sincerity, Excitement, Competence, Sophistication, and Ruggedness. In a global analysis of brands, Aaker and her colleagues revealed two novel brand personality dimensions. In Japan, individuals viewed brands as Peaceful, and in Spain, individuals viewed brands as Passionate. Aaker’s model showed that brand personality dimensions influence consumer preference and choice and provided a framework that illuminated how to build strong global brands that meet multi-cultural needs.{{cite journal|last=Aaker|first=Jennifer|title=Dimensions of Brand Personality|date=August 1997|url=http://www.haas.berkeley.edu/groups/finance/Papers/Dimensions%20of%20BP%20JMR%201997.pdf|accessdate=16 June 2013}} In 2002, Aaker shifted her research focus to understanding time, money and happiness. In this work, she suggested that time is a resource that, like money, is not only important but more subjective than we think. In 2010, she published two papers with [[Sepandar Kamvar|Sep Kamvar]] and Cassie Mogilner on the dynamic meaning of happiness. Prior research had suggested that the meaning of happiness is either similar across individuals, or highly subjective and idiosyncratic. Aaker and her colleagues show that the answer lies between the two and that there is in fact a predictable shift in the meaning of happiness and how it is experienced over one's life and even within the day or week. The research also showed that the meaning of happiness that one holds impacts the choices people make. Aaker has also examined questions such as why people give to others, how small acts create significant change, and how those effects can be fueled by social media. In 2010, Aaker and her husband, startup advisor Andy Smith, authored the book ''The Dragonfly Effect: Quick, Effective and Powerful Ways to Use Social Media to Drive Social Change.''{{cite web|title=The Dragonfly Effect|url=http://www.dragonflyeffect.com/|work=2013|publisher=Official Website|accessdate=16 June 2013}} With a title inspired by the dragonfly’s unique ability to propel itself in any direction when its four wings worked in concert, the book examined the manner in which synchronized ideas can be used to create rapid transformations through social media. A literary award winner,[5] ''The Dragonfly Effect'' has been translated into over 10 languages. In 2013, Aaker, Smith and McCarthy published ''The Power of Stories'', a companion to ''The Dragonfly Effect'', which further explored social media through psychological insight and provided a hands-on tool to help companies put the model to work. In a real world demonstration of the Dragonfly Effect, Aaker and her students founded 100K Cheeks,.{{cite web|last=David|first=Avril|title=Names You Need to Know|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/avrildavid/2011/05/17/names-you-need-to-know-the-dragonfly-effect/|work=May 17, 2011|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=16 June 2013}}{{Cite book|title=The Power of Stores|ISBN=1484184386}} an organization dedicated to registering 100,000 South Asian donors in the National Bone Marrow Registry.{{cite web|title=Past Challenges (Get Involved) |url=http://studentaffairs.stanford.edu/haas/100kcheeks |publisher=Haas Center for Public Service |accessdate=13 July 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131221230214/http://studentaffairs.stanford.edu/haas/100kcheeks |archivedate=21 December 2013 |df= }} In addition to utilizing social networks, Aaker ran the first ever cheek swab in India; as a result of these efforts, 100K Cheeks exceeded their goal by registering more than 115,000 potential donors.{{cite web|title=Jennifer Aaker: Pursuit of Happiness|url=http://www.inktalks.com/discover/53/pursuit-of-happiness|work=November 27, 2011|publisher=Ink Talks|accessdate=19 June 2013}}{{cite book|last=Beth Kanter Katie Delahaye Paine|first=Katie Delahaye Paine|title=Measuring the Networked Nonprofit: Using Data to Change the World|year=2012|publisher=Wiley|location=New York|isbn=978-1-118-13760-4|url=https://books.google.com/?id=vL_lhYF0Uf4C&pg=PT36&lpg=PT36&dq=jennifer+aaker+100k+cheeks}}{{cite web|title=The Dragonfly Effect|url=http://www.ssireview.org/articles/entry/the_dragonfly_effect|work=October 2011|publisher=Stanford Social Innovation Review|accessdate=16 June 2013}} "Social media is not inherently meaningful," Aaker said in an interview on the subject. "Yet the power of social technology, when fully engaged, can be nothing short of revolutionary."{{cite web|last=Staff Writer|title=100k Cheeks and Blood Center to Host Marrow Drive|url=http://www.stanforddaily.com/2011/02/01/100k-cheeks-and-blood-center-to-host-bone-marrow-drive/|work=February 1, 2011|publisher=Stanford Daily|accessdate=16 June 2013}} == Books == * {{cite book |first1= Jennifer |last1= Aaker |title= The Dragonfly Effect: Quick, Effective, and Powerful Ways To Use Social Media to Drive Social Change |first2= Andy |last2= Smith |date= September 2010 |publisher= Jossey-Bass |isbn= 978-0-470-61415-0 }}{{cite book |title= The Dragonfly Effect: Quick, Effective, and Powerful Ways To Use Social Media to Drive Social Change |first1= Jennifer Lynn |last1= Aaker |first2= Andy |last2= Smith |others= Carlye Adler |publisher= Jossey-Bass |location= San Francisco |date= 2010 |isbn= 9780470614150 |oclc= 460061966 }} * {{cite book |first3= Jennifer |last3= Aaker |title= Dragonfly Effect Workbook: The Power of Stories |first1= Andrew |last1= Smith |first2= Barbara |last2= McCarthy |date= April 2013 |publisher= [[CreateSpace]] |isbn= 978-1-4841-8438-7 |url= https://www.createspace.com/4255497 }} * {{cite book |contributor-first1= Jennifer |contributor-last1= Aaker |contribution= Text |title= Keep Calm, Play Hard: One Player's Journey in New York City |first1= Cooper |last1= Smith |date= November 2013 |isbn= 978-1494278342 |publisher= CreateSpace |url= https://www.createspace.com/4542264 }} * {{cite book |contributor-first1= Jennifer |contributor-last1= Aaker |contribution= Text |title= Tea Sloane's Adventure: A Sparkly Tale of Whimsy and Meaning Found in NYC |first1= Tea Sloane |last1= Smith |date= December 2013 |publisher= CreateSpace |isbn= 9781494471064 |url= https://www.createspace.com/4570510 }} * {{cite book |contributor-first1= Jennifer |contributor-last1= Aaker |contribution= Text |title= Devon Made It: One Boy's Journey in NYC |first1= Devon |last1= Smith |date= December 2013 |url= https://www.createspace.com/4560010 |isbn= 9781494400811 |publisher= CreateSpace }} == Selected publications == * {{cite journal |title= Some Key Differences between a Happy Life and a Meaningful Life |first= Roy F. |last1= Baumeister |first2= Kathleen D. |last2= Vohs |first3= Jennifer |last3= Aaker |first4= Emily N. |last4= Garbinsky |journal= Journal of Positive Psychology |date= 2013 |volume= 8 |issue= 6 |pages= 505–516 |url= https://www.gsb.stanford.edu/faculty-research/publications/some-key-differences-between-happy-life-meaningful-life |doi= 10.1080/17439760.2013.830764 }} *''How Happiness Impacts Choice'' (2012), Mogilner, Aaker and Kamvar, JCR *''Awe Expands People's Perception of Time and Enhances Well-Being'' (2012), Rudd, Vohs, and Aaker, Psychological Science. *''If Money Doesn't Make You Happy, Consider Time'' (2011), Aaker, Rudd, and Mogilner, JCP *''The Shifting Meaning of Happiness'' (2010) Mogilner, Kamvar and Aaker, SPPS *''Non-Profits Are Seen as Warm and For-Profits as Competent'' (2010), Aaker, Vohs and Mogilner, JCR *''The Time versus Money Effect'' (2009), Mogilner and Aaker, JCR *''The Happiness of Giving: The Time-Ask Effect'' (2008), Liu and Aaker, JCR *''When Good Brands Do Bad'' (2004), Aaker, Fournier, and Brasel, JCR *''Can Mixed Emotions Peacefully Co-Exist?'' (2002), Williams and Aaker, JCR *''Consumption Symbols as Carriers of Culture'' (2001), Aaker, Benet-Martínez, and Garolera, JPSP *''Dimensions of Brand Personality'' (1997), Aaker, JMR == Honors and awards == *Distinguished Scientific Contribution Award, Society for Consumer Psychology, 2014{{cite web|title=SCP Distinguished Scientific Contribution Award|url=http://www.apa.org/about/awards/div-23-scpscicon.aspx?tab=4|publisher=[[American Psychological Association]]|accessdate=May 9, 2015}} *Robert K. Jaedicke Silver Apple Award, Stanford, 2011{{cite web|title=Robert K. Jaedicke Silver Apple Award recipients|url=http://www.gsb.stanford.edu/alumni/featured-events/award-events/silver-apple|publisher=[[Stanford Graduate School of Business]]|accessdate=May 9, 2015}} *Early Career Award for Outstanding Research, Society for Consumer Psychology, 2003{{cite web|title=Honorees |url=http://www.myscp.org/about/honorees.aspx#.VU5zFvlViko |publisher=Society for Consumer Psychology |accessdate=May 9, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130324234737/http://www.myscp.org/about/honorees.aspx |archivedate=March 24, 2013 |df= }} *Distinguished Teaching Award, Stanford, 2000 *Citibank Best Teacher Award, UCLA, 1999 *George Robbins Best Teacher Award, UCLA, 1998 == See also== * [[Innovation]] * [[Creativity]] * [[Narrative|Story]] * [[Design thinking]] * [[Customer engagement]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} == External links == *[http://faculty-gsb.stanford.edu/aaker/ Jennifer Aaker at Stanford Graduate School of Business] *[http://www.stanford.edu/class/mktg353/ Building Innovative Brands] *[http://stanford.edu/class/gsbgen542/ The Power of Story] *[http://www.stanford.edu/class/mktg355/ Designing (for) Happiness] *[http://www.dragonflyeffect.com/ The Dragonfly Effect] {{DEFAULTSORT:Aaker, Jennifer}} [[Category:1967 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American social psychologists]] [[Category:American marketing people]] [[Category:Stanford Graduate School of Business alumni]] [[Category:Stanford University Graduate School of Business faculty]] [[Category:Marketing theorists]] [[Category:Marketing women]] [[Category:People from Lafayette, California]] [[Category:Writers from Palo Alto, California]]

revision.text:
'''Kathryn Aalto''' is an American landscape designer, historian, educator and New York Times Bestselling author<ref name=NYTFeb>[https://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers-books/2016-02-07/travel/list.html New York Times Bestseller List, Travel, February 2016]</ref> based in [[Exeter, England]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Youlden|first1=Mary|title=Exeter Lives: Kathryn Aalto|url=http://www.theexeterdaily.co.uk/news/blogs/exeter-lives-kathryn-aalto|accessdate=17 May 2016|publisher=The Exeter Daily|date=31 August 2013}}</ref>
== Early life == Kathryn Aalto grew up between San Francisco and the Sierras in California's San Joaquin Valley where she developed a lifelong interest in landscape history, design and literature of place. She was educated at the [[University of California at Berkeley]], [[Western Washington University]], the London College of Garden Design<ref>{{cite web|title=London College of Garden Design|url=http://www.lcgd.org.uk/|accessdate=27 June 2016}}</ref> and the [[University of Bristol]], from which she received a Bachelor’s in English, a Master’s in English, a Diploma in Garden Design and a Master’s in Garden History.
== Career ==
=== Books === Kathryn Aalto is best known for her book, ''The Natural World of Winnie-the-Pooh: A Walk Through the Forest that Inspired the Hundred Acre Wood,''<ref name="The Oregonian">{{cite news|last1=Eastman|first1=Janet|title=Winnie-the-Pooh's real forest: Meet author Kathryn Aalto (photos)|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/hg/index.ssf/2016/02/natural_world_of_winnie-the-po_1.html|accessdate=12 May 2016|publisher=The Oregonian|date=3 February 2016}}</ref> published in 2015 by [[Timber Press]], which became a [[New York Times Bestseller]] in February 2016.<ref name=NYTFeb /> It was featured on NPR's "All Things Considered" on October 26, 2015 and selected as a People magazine Best Pick in Nonfiction in November 2015. Extensive coverage of the book included an article<ref>{{cite news|last1=Higgins|first1=Adrian|title=The real forest that inspired the stories of Winnie-the-Pooh|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/home/the-real-forest-that-inspired-the-stories-of-winnie-the-pooh/2015/11/10/7cedc4bc-8331-11e5-a7ca-6ab6ec20f839_story.html|accessdate=12 May 2016|publisher=The Washington Post|date=11 November 2015}}</ref> and review<ref>{{cite news|last1=Quattlebaum|first1=Mary|title=‘The Natural World of Winnie-the-Pooh’ is a honey pot of nostalgia|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/books/the-natural-world-of-winnie-the-pooh-is-a-honey-pot-of-nostalgia/2015/10/15/58914cd6-63bc-11e5-b38e-06883aacba64_story.html|accessdate=24 June 2016|agency=The Washington Post|date=15 October 2015}}</ref> in [[The Washington Post]], articles in [[The Boston Globe]]<ref>{{cite news|last1=Tuttle|first1=Kate|title=Landscape historian Kathryn Aalto on Winnie-the-Pooh’s forest|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/arts/books/2015/11/14/story-behind-book-landscape-historian-kathryn-aalto-winnie-pooh-forest/2iLvjEarwFbSvDwKKEydJM/story.html|accessdate=12 May 2016|publisher=The Boston Globe|date=14 November 2015}}</ref> and [[The Oregonian]],<ref name="The Oregonian"/> as well as radio interviews on NPR,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Shapiro|first1=Ari|title=The real forest that inspired the stories of Winnie-the-Pooh|url=https://www.npr.org/2016/01/18/463503941/the-real-woods-behind-winnie-the-poohs-forest|accessdate=12 May 2016|publisher=Northeast Public Radio (NPR)|date=18 January 2016}}</ref> WAMC<ref>{{cite news|last1=Donahue|first1=Joe|title=The Natural World Of Winnie-The-Pooh|url=http://wamc.org/term/preseration#stream/0|accessdate=12 May 2016|publisher=WAMC|date=21 October 2015}}</ref> and MPR.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Mumford|first1=Tracy|title=Inside Winnie-the-Pooh's real Hundred Acre Wood|url=http://www.mprnews.org/story/2015/11/04/bcst-books-hundred-acre-wood|accessdate=12 May 2016|publisher=MPR|date=4 November 2015}}</ref> She is also the author of Nature and Human Intervention<ref>{{Cite book|title=Nature and Human Intervention|website=Amazon|id= {{ASIN|0957035500|country=uk}}}}</ref> for Italian garden designer Luciano Guibbilei.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Heather|first1=Duncan|title=New Book by Luciano Giubbilei: Nature and Human Intervention|url=http://gardendesigncourses.blogspot.co.uk/2011/10/new-book-by-luciano-giubbilei-nature.html|accessdate=24 June 2016|publisher=Oxford College of Garden Design|date=October 2011}}</ref>
*{{cite book|last1=Aalto|first1=Kathryn|title=The Natural World of Winnie-the-Pooh: A Walk Through the Forest that Inspired the Hundred Acre Wood|date=2015|publisher=[[Timber Press]]|isbn=978-1604695991}}.<ref>[http://www.gilbertwhiteshouse.org.uk/2016/05/qa-kathryn-aalto/ Gilbert White & The Oates Collections, Q&A With Kathryn Aalto, ''12 May 2016'']</ref> This book appeared on [[The New York Times Best Seller list|New York Times bestseller list]] in February 2016.<ref name=NYTFeb /> *{{cite book|last1=Aalto|first1=Kathryn|last2=Giubbilei|first2=Luciano|title=Nature and Human Intervention|date=2011|publisher=Luciano Giubbilei Design|isbn=9780957035508}}
=== Teaching and public speaking === As an educator, she has taught American Literature of Nature and Place, Critical Thinking and Composition and other writing courses at [[Western Washington University]], [[Everett Community College]] and [[Exeter College, Exeter|Exeter College]] where she is an adjunct lecturer.<ref>{{cite web|title=Speaker Profile - Kathryn Aalto|url=http://www.scbwi.org/speakers/kathryn-aalto|website=Society of Children’s Book Writers and Illustrators|accessdate=17 May 2016}}</ref> A dynamic public speaker, Kathryn Aalto lectures widely, both in the United States and England, on landscape history and creative careers to libraries, schools, historical societies, botanical gardens, universities and civic clubs. Past venues have included Harvard Universities [[Arnold Arboretum]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=The Arnold Arboretum|title=The Natural World of Winnie-the-Pooh: The Forest that Inspired the Hundred Acre Wood|url=https://my.arboretum.harvard.edu/info.aspx?ActivityID=2254|website=The Arnold Arboretum|accessdate=17 May 2016|date=15 November 2015}}</ref> [[The New York Public Library]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=The New York Public Library|title=Children's Literary Salon: The Natural World of Winnie-the-Pooh|url=http://www.nypl.org/events/programs/2015/10/17/childrens-literary-salon-natural-world-winnie-pooh|website=The New York Public Library|accessdate=17 May 2016|date=17 October 2015}}</ref> the [[Northwest Flower and Garden Show]]<ref>{{cite web|last1=Northwest Flower and Garden Show|title=KATHRYN AALTO: U.K. WRITER, DESIGNER AND AUTHOR, THE NATURAL WORLD OF WINNIE-THE-POOH|url=https://www.gardenshow.com/seminars/speaker-info/kathryn-aalto/|website=Northwest Flower and Garden Show|accessdate=17 May 2016|date=17 February 2016}}</ref> and the Virginia Festival of the Book.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Virginia Festival of the Book 2016|title=Speaker: Kathryn Aalto|url=http://vabook16.vfhblogs.org/participant/kathryn-aalto/|website=Virginia Festival of the Book|accessdate=17 May 2016|date=17 March 2016}}</ref> She also gives inspirational talks on interdisciplinary careers, creativity and writing.
== Personal life == Kathryn Aalto resides in Exeter, England. She has lived in [[Escalon]], [[Berkeley, California|Berkeley]], [[Seattle]], [[Monroe, Washington|Monroe]] and [[Exeter, England]]
== References == <!--- See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes on how to create references using<ref></ref> tags, these references will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
== External links == * {{Official website|http://www.kathrynaalto.com/}} * [http://www.timberpress.com/books/natural_world_winnie_pooh/aalto/9781604695991/ Official Timber Press page for ''The Natural World Of Winnie-the-Pooh: A Walk Through the Forest that Inspired the Hundred Acre Wood''] * [http://wamc.org/term/preseration#stream/0/ NPR Interview on Northeast Public Radio] * [https://www.npr.org/2016/01/18/463503941/the-real-woods-behind-winnie-the-poohs-forest/ NPR Interview on "All Things Considered."] * [http://www.kathrynaalto.com/about/ Debate at RHS Wisley]
{{authority control}}

revision.comment: Add [[Emerging church]] to see also - article has whole section describing Missional living as a major feature of the movement
revision.text:
{{tone|date=April 2013}} In [[Christianity]], '''missional living''' is the adoption of the posture, thinking, behaviors, and practices of a [[Mission (Christian)|missionary]] in order to engage others with the [[Good news (Christianity)|gospel]] message. The missional church movement, a [[church renewal]] movement predicated on the necessity of missional living by Christians, gained popularity at the end of the twentieth century due to advocates like [[Timothy J. Keller|Tim Keller]] and others in the Gospel and Our Culture Network. Advocates contrast missional living with the concept of a select group of "professional" missionaries, emphasizing that all Christians should be involved in the [[Great Commission]] of [[Jesus Christ]].Tim Keller, "The Missional church by Tim Keller" http://download.redeemer.com/pdf/learn/resources/Missional_Church-Keller.pdf ==Understanding ''Missional''== The missional living concept is rooted in the ''[[Missio dei]]'' (Latin, "the sending of God"). In 1934, Karl Hartenstein, a German [[Missiology|missiologist]], coined the phrase in response to [[Karl Barth]] and his emphasis on ''actio Dei'' ("the action of God"). In their view, missional activities stemming from God.Bosch, David J, Transforming Mission: Paradigm Shifts in Theology of Mission (Maryknoll, NY: Orbis Books, 1991), 420. The Triune God is the primary acting agent in the world and within the church. According to Lesslie Newbigin and Jesus' statements in the Gospel according to John, every Christian has been sent by Jesus with the gospel together in community to those in the surrounding culture for the sake of the King and His kingdom: “The Church is sent into the world to continue that which he came to do, in the power of the same Spirit, reconciling people to God.”[[Lesslie Newbigin]], ''The Gospel in a Pluralist Society'', Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing Co., 1989, 230. Jesus said, “As the Father has sent Me, I am sending you” (John 20:21).
"No one can say: ‘Since I’m not called to be a missionary, I do not have to evangelize my friends and neighbors.’ There is no difference, in spiritual terms, between a missionary witnessing in his home town and a missionary witnessing in Katmandu, Nepal. We are all called to go—even if it is only to the next room, or the next block.”"Thomas Hale, ''On Being a Missionary'', p 6
==A missional (missionary) perspective== ''Missional living'' is the embodiment of the mission of Jesus in the world by incarnating the gospel. "It is imperative that Christians be like Jesus, by living freely within the culture as missionaries who are as faithful to the Father and his gospel as Jesus was in his own time and place."[[Mark Driscoll (pastor)|Mark Driscoll]], ''The Radical Reformission'', Zondervan, 2004, 40. This embodiment of the gospel is often referred to as "contextualization" or "inculturation."
"Both refer to more than a simple translation of the gospel into different languages and cultures in the way that one translates a history book or a science text. Rather, they point to the embodiment of the living Word in human culture and social settings in such a way that its divine nature and power are not lost. True contextualization is more than communication. It is God working in the hearts of people, making them new and forming them into a new community. It is his Word transforming their lives, their societies, their cultures."Paul Hiebert and Eliose Hiebert Meneses, ''Incarnational Ministry'', Baker Book House, 1995, 370.
These five biblical distinctives form the foundation of a missional perspective:Dave DeVries, ''Missional Transformation: Fueling Missionary Movements that Transform America'', Bakke Graduate University, 2007, 8-12. # The Church is sent by Jesus Christ (John 17:18; 20:21, Luke 9:2; Matt 28: 19–20; Acts 1:8) # The Church is sent with the Cross (1 Cor 1:18, Eph 2:16, Col 2:14, 1 Pet2:24, 2 Cor 5:17–24) # The Church is sent in Community (Acts 2:42–47; 5:42; John 13:34–35; 1 John 3:16–17) # The Church is sent to every Culture (John 1:14; Matt 20:28; Acts 17:22–34; Luke 5:29) # The Church is sent for the King and His Kingdom (Matt 10:7; 25:34; Luke 4:43; Rev 11:15–17; Jer 10:7; John 18:36) [[Image:A Missional Perspective.JPG]] ===Sent=== Jesus sent His disciples on a mission. The missional church defines itself in terms of its mission—being sent ones who take the gospel to and incarnate the gospel within a specific culture.
"Jesus was the first apostle. He was sent by his Father. He, in turn, sent the Twelve. They went to people who would then take the gospel to the rest of the world. Whoever received it would understand that they, too, had been sent. With the gospel being what it is, the church as bearer of the gospel is bound to be apostolic."Jim Petersen and Mike Shamy, ''The Insider'', NavPress, 2003, 83.
===Cross=== Jesus Christ said that He came to earth to seek and to save that which was lost (Luke 19:10). He accomplished salvation through the cross. By dying on the cross, He paid the penalty for sin and satisfied God’s wrath. According to Scripture, without the cross, there is no salvation, no forgiveness, and no hope; because of the cross, there is eternal life. The mission and message of Jesus surround the cross. “For the word of the cross is to those who are perishing foolishness, but to us who are being saved it is the power of God” (1 Cor 1:18). ===Community=== Jesus loves the Church and He gave His life to redeem the Church. Community exists for Mission! Christians are to bring the gospel ''together'' to the culture. "The church is called to ''do'' the work of Christ, to be the means of his ''action'' in and for the world....Mission, in its widest as well as its more focused senses, is what the church is there for. God intends to put the world to rights; he has dramatically launched this project through Jesus. Those who belong to Jesus are called, here and now, in the power of the Spirit, to be agents of that putting-to-rights purpose."[[N. T. Wright]], ''Simply Christian'', HarperSanFrancisco, 2006, 201, 204. ===Culture=== George Peters notes, “If man is to be reached, he must be reached within his own culture.”George Peters, ''A Biblical Theology of Missions'', Moody Press, 163. This principle is observed when God became a man in the form of Jesus to come to earth and incarnate the gospel. As missionaries sent by Jesus, every Christian must learn to exegete their surrounding culture, uncovering the language, values, and ideas of the culture. Using this information, they take steps to reach people with the gospel message in the context of the surrounding culture. ===King and Kingdom=== The kingdom was central to Jesus’ message and mission. The Book of Acts ends with Paul, under house arrest in Rome, “proclaiming the kingdom of God and teaching about the Lord Jesus Christ with all boldness and without hindrance” (Acts 28:31). Christians are sent to proclaim the gospel of the kingdom so that others may enter the kingdom. George Hunsberger conveys the idea that the Church is pointing beyond itself to the kingdom of God. The Church is not an end in itself; God has a mission that goes beyond the Church which includes the kingdom. The kingdom and the Church must never be divorced, yet they also must never be equated. In a similar way, “the reign must never be separated from the One who reigns.”George R. Hunsberger, “Called and Sent to Represent the Reign of God,” in ''Missional Church'', ed. Darrel Guder, Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing Co., 1998, 94. The kingdom is always at the heart of the King. ==The missional church== The missional church movement first arose during the end of the 20th century and the beginning of the 21st century. The movement seeks to rethink and redefine the nature of the church and create a new paradigm in which churches are seen as missional in nature, instead of attractional in nature. Leaders in the movement argue that instead of churches attempting to attract people to churches through church programs, churches should instead take the gospel outside of the church and engage society with the gospel, often by being involved not only in missions and evangelism but also in social justice movements. The missional church defines itself in terms of its mission — being ''sent ones'' who take the gospel to and incarnate the gospel within a specific cultural context.
The church exists, in other words, for what we sometimes call "mission": to announce to the world that Jesus is its Lord.[[Tom Wright (theologian)|N. T. Wright]], ''Simply Christian'', 2006, 204.
"Mission is not just a program of the church. It defines the church as God’s sent people. Either we are defined by mission, or we reduce the scope of the gospel and the mandate of the church. Thus our challenge today is to move from church with mission to missional church."Guder, ed., ''Missional Church'', 6.
The [[Christian church|Church]] has a mission because Jesus has a mission. There is one mission.
"Missional church is a community of God’s people that defines itself, and organizes its life around, its real purpose of being an agent of God’s mission to the world. In other words, the church’s true and authentic [[organizing principle]] is mission. When the church is in mission, it is the true church. The church itself is not only a product of that mission but is obligated and destined to extend it by whatever means possible. The mission of God flows directly through every believer and every community of faith that adheres to Jesus. To obstruct this is to block God’s purposes in and through his people." [[Alan Hirsch]], ''The Forgotten Ways'', Brazos, 2007, 82.
Missional living is a term that is used in contrast with historical institutional churches. Church leaders as well as Christians in general have often regarded the Church as an institution to which outsiders must come in order to receive a certain product, namely, the gospel and all its associated benefits. Institutional churches are sometimes perceived to exist for the members and depend on pastors and staff to evangelize the lost. The "missional church", on the other hand, attempts to take Christ to "the lost" and its members are personally engaged in reaching their communities with the message of Jesus Christ. == See also == * [[Inculturation]] * [[Missio dei]] * [[Anchor Gaslamp]] * [[Missional community]] * [[Mosaic Church]] * [[Dan Kimball]] * [[Emerging church]] * [[Erwin McManus]] * [[Mark Driscoll (pastor)|Mark Driscoll]] * [[Brian McLaren]] * [[Don Miller (author)]] * [[Derek Webb]] ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== '''Theological and Philosophical Background''' * John Bailey (Editor). ''Pursuing the Mission of God in Church Planting: The Missional Church in North America'', NAMB (2007) * [[David Bosch]]. ''Transforming Mission'', Orbis Books, (1991) * Neil Cole. ''Organic Church'', Jossey-Bass (2005) * David DeVries. ''Six-Word Lessons to Discover Missional Living'', Leading on the Edge (August 2010). * [[Michael Frost (minister)|Michael Frost]]. ''Exiles: Living Missionally in a Post-Christian Culture'', Hendrickson Publishers (July 25, 2006). * Michael Frost and [[Alan Hirsch]]. ''The Shaping of Things to Come: Innovation and Mission for the 21st-Century Church'', Hendrickson Publishers (November 2003). * [[Darrell Guder]] (Editor), ''Missional Church: A Vision for the Sending of the Church in North America'', Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing Company (February 1998). * Ross Hastings, ''Missional God, Missional Church: Hope for Re-Evangelizing the West'', IVP Academic (2012). * [[Alan Hirsch]]. ''The Forgotten Ways: Reactivating the Missional Church'', Brazos (2007). * [[George R. Hunsberger]] and [[Craig Van Gelder]] eds., ''The Church Between Gospel and Culture: The Emerging Mission in North America'', Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing Company (March 1996). * Helen Lee. ''The Missional Mom'', Moody Publishers, (January 2011) *Patrick Keifert. ''We Are Here Now: A New Missional Era'', Church Innovations Institute (2006) * [[Dan Kimball]]. ''They Like Jesus But Not the Church'', Zondervan (2007) * [[Lesslie Newbigin]]. ''The Open Secret'', Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing Company (February 1995) * [[Lesslie Newbigin]]. ''The Gospel in a Pluralist Society'', Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing Company (December 1989) '''Practical Implications''' * [[JR Woodward]] ''Creating a Missional Culture: Equipping the Church for the Sake of the World'', InterVarsity Press (2012) * [[Alan J. Roxburgh]] ''The Missionary Congregation, Leadership & Liminality'', Trinity Press International (1997) * Alan J. Roxburgh and [[Fred Romanuk]]. ''The Missional Leader: Equipping Your Church to Reach a Changing World'', Jossey-Bass (April 7, 2006). * [[Ed Stetzer]] and [[David Putman]]. ''Breaking the Missional Code'', B&H Publishing Group (May 2006). * Craig Van Gelder ''The Essence of the Church: A Community Created by the Spirit'', Baker Books (2000) * Craig Van Gelder ''The Ministry of the Missional Church: A Community Led by the Spirit'', Baker Books (2007) * Frank Viola. ''From Eternity to Here'', David C. Cook (2009) ; == External links == * See the [http://www.tyndale.ca/seminary/mtsmodular/reading-rooms/missional Missional Church Reading Room] for extensive on-line library (Tyndale Seminary) {{DEFAULTSORT:Missional Living}} [[Category:Missional Christianity| ]] [[Category:Christian terminology]] [[Category:Philosophy of life]] [[Category:Christian movements]] [[Category:Ecclesiology]]

revision.text:
{{original research|date=July 2018}} {{Short pages monitor}}<!-- This long comment was added to the page to prevent it from being listed on Special:Shortpages. It and the accompanying monitoring template were generated via Template:Long comment. Please do not remove the monitor template without removing the comment as well.--> {{unreferenced|date=October 2010}} '''Mortality [[forecasting]]''' refers to the art and science of determining likely future mortality rates. It is especially important in rich countries with a high proportion of aged people, since aged populations are expensive in terms of [[pensions]] (both public and private). It is a major topic in [[Ageing]] studies.
==See also==
* [[Lee-Carter model]] * [[Life expectancy]] * [[Actuarial science]]
[[Category:Actuarial science]] [[Category:Death]] [[Category:Forecasting]]

page.title: Mortality in the early modern age

revision.text:
{{cleanup|reason=fix lead, edit to be more specific to the EMP, edit for flow/style|date=July 2018}} The early modern age saw various economic changes as well as several significant diseases that have affected the mortality rates. Data collection during this time was not consistent or broadly recorded and there have been efforts to reconstruct plausible statistics.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Laqueur|first=Thomas|title=The Work of the Dead: A Cultural History of Mortal Remains|journal=Journal of the History of Medicine and Allied Sciences|volume=72|issue=4|pages=504–506|doi=10.1093/jhmas/jrx024|issn=0022-5045|via=|year=2017}}</ref> Mortality rates vary on geographic location, social environment, and cultural values.<ref name=":1" /> There were also gender differences in the mortality rates, leading to an excess mortality rate in urban areas and in the female population.<ref name=":1">{{Citation|last=Derosas|first=Renzo|title=Life Under Pressure: Mortality And Living Standards In Europe And Asia, 1700-1900|date=|url=|work=Infant and Child Mortality|volume=|pages=327–398, 431–440|publisher=|isbn=|access-date=2018-07-24|last2=Breschi|first2=Marco|last3=Fornasin|first3=Alessio|last4=Manfredini|first4=Matteo|last5=Munno|first5=Cristina}}</ref> A main cause of death was [[stillbirth]], which could be attributed to, but not limited to, maternal infections, birth complications, and congenital anomalies.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.who.int/maternal_child_adolescent/epidemiology/stillbirth/en/|title=Stillbirths|website=World Health Organization|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-07-24}}</ref> Another contributing factor to the mortality rate was food insecurity and shortages as well as unemployment, both of which varied per region.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Post|first=John D.|date=1990|title=The Mortality Crises of the Early 1770s and European Demographic Trends|journal=Journal of Interdisciplinary History|volume=21|issue=1|pages=29|doi=10.2307/204917|issn=0022-1953|jstor=204917}}</ref> A final factor was violence, which occurred mainly due to [[Structural violence|structural]] or systemic violence; however, violence since the 12th century has been steadily falling.<ref>{{Citation|last=Campbell|first=Roderick Campbell|title=Toward a Deep History of Violence and Civilization|url=http://ebookcentral.proquest.com/lib/ucsc/detail.action?docID=2084655|work=Violence and Civilization: Studies of Social Violence in History and Prehistory|volume=|pages=1–22|publisher=|isbn=9781782976202|access-date=2018-07-25|date=2013-12-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title=Steven Pinker on the myth of violence|last=Pinker|first=Steven|date=2007|website=PsycEXTRA Dataset|doi = 10.1037/e597002010-001}}</ref>
== Data Collection == Data from the early modern age was not accurately or consistently collected. However, there have been a number of studies and reconstructed statistics from this era, particularly on children and women. There has not been any empirical research published and the only information has been theoretical as there has been insufficient data and sources.<ref name=":0" /> It was also common for many statistics to go unreported; this is especially true regarding unmarried women.<ref name=":1" /> Models and theoretic equations need to take into account "social, economic, cultural, geographical, and even climatological variables" in order to accurately reflect the statistics of the time.<ref name=":1" />
== Gender differences == One study, the Eurasia Project, has shown that boys, especially those under one year, had a higher mortality rate during childhood than girls, but the mortality rate for men and women were about equal. It has also been shown that there is a higher male mortality than female mortality rate during the time of famine. Male mortality has also been linked to "economic modernization and urbanization ... especially for cardiovascular disease".<ref name=":1" />
Women faced increased mortality during childbirth as pregnancy and childbirth compromised the mother's immune system, with the most common causes of death being [[Postpartum infections|puerperal fever]], [[Pre-eclampsia|toxemia]], and [[Postpartum bleeding|hemorrhage]]. These dangers suggest an association to the excess female mortality, especially considering that women had to compete more for resources as they had no property rights and had a lower ranking in the household hierarchy. The average age of childbearing differed between Asia and Europe with an average difference of five years, which would affect cross-cultural data collection. Children born to mothers 35 years or older had a higher risk of mortality than children born to younger mothers. linking a mother's health and a child's survival.<ref name=":1" />
Female infants and children often had a higher mortality rate, especially in times of food insecurity, compared to male infants and children. However, a maternal presence worked as a protective factor for children. regardless of age or gender.<ref name=":1" />
== Economics == Food insecurity and shortages were common throughout this time period and were matched with the high food prices and high unemployment rate.<ref name=":3" /> This is shown through the differences in mortality rates between the lower and upper class, with poor infants being up to two times more likely to die than their wealthier counterparts.<ref name=":1" /> In 17th century Europe, it was common that at least one in five children from the same family would die before the age of one.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/21375348|title=Making sex : body and gender from the Greeks to Freud|last=Walter.|first=Laqueur, Thomas|date=1990|publisher=Harvard University Press|isbn=978-0674543492|location=Cambridge, Mass.|oclc=21375348}}</ref> Because of this high rate, it was common for there to be a large amount of children in one family so that there would be a higher rate of survival. Especially among poorer families, having multiple children was common in order to ensure there would be children to contribute to the family later on.<ref name=":1" />
During the early modern era, house calls were common. If the patient was female, the doctor, commonly an upper class male, would typically be summoned by a male family member who wound remain throughout the examination. The physician and male family member would then discuss the diagnosis and treatment plan without the female's input. This practice reinforced and perpetuated social hierarchies and patriarchal values.<ref name=":4">{{Cite book|last=Furth|first=Charlotte|date=1999-03-05|title=A Flourishing Yin: Gender in China's Medical History|journal=Isis|volume=93|issue=3|pages=479–480|doi=10.1086/374084|isbn=9780520208292|via=}}</ref>
== Death and diseases ==
Food shortages and insecurity were leading concerns in the 18th century, especially in Europe, and these were exacerbated by reduced harvests yields.<ref name=":3" /> Disease was another leading cause of death, with rats and fleas being the common carriers of disease, specifically plagues, during this era.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/plague/faq/index.html|title=FAQ {{!}} Plague {{!}} CDC|website=www.cdc.gov|language=en-us|access-date=2018-07-24}}</ref>
The [[Black Death]] was a plague that affected much of the world, originating in Asia and spreading to Europe through diseased fleas and rats. This epidemic has been reported to have been the cause of death for approximately "60% of the European population".<ref name=":2" />
During the end of the 19th century, there was a plague, known as the [[Third plague pandemic|Modern Plague]], that started in China and spread to different cities through ports, reportedly causing roughly ten million deaths.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/plague/history/index.html|title=History {{!}} Plague {{!}} CDC|date=2018-05-31|website=www.cdc.gov|language=en-us|access-date=2018-07-24}}</ref> This plague affected Asia, the Americas, and Africa and lasted into the 20th century.<ref name=":2" /> There were also epidemics that occurred locally and did not spread to national levels, notably in 18th century England.<ref name=":3" /> These local epidemics included fevers, dysentery, smallpox, starvation, typhoid fever, under-nutrition, cholera, malaria.<ref name=":3" />
By the end of the era, [[disease]] and [[malnutrition]] were no longer the main leading causes of death.<ref name=":1" />
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Death]]

contributor.username: Me, Myself, and I are Here

revision.comment: dashes, alpha
revision.text:
{{distinguish|Nanobacteria|Ultramicrobacteria}}
A '''nanobe''' is a tiny filamental [[structure]] first found in some [[Rock (geology)|rocks]] and [[sediment]]s. Some scientists [[Hypothesis|hypothesize]] that nanobes are the smallest form of [[life]], 1/10 the size of the [[Mycoplasma|smallest known]] [[Bacterium|bacteria]].<ref name=Nanjundiah2000>{{Cite journal | last = Nanjundiah | first = V. | year = 2000 | title = The smallest form of life yet? | journal = Journal of Biosciences | volume = 25 | issue = 1 | pages = 9–10 | url = http://eprints.iisc.ernet.in/archive/00001799/01/25smallest25(1)-9to10mar2000.pdf | doi = 10.1007/BF02985175 | pmid = 10824192 | postscript = <!--None-->}}</ref>
No conclusive evidence exists that these structures are, or are not, living organisms, so their classification is controversial.
The 1996 discovery of nanobes was published in 1998<ref name=nanobepaper1998>{{cite journal|author=Uwins, Philippa, J. R.|url=http://www.microscopy-uk.org.uk/nanobes/nanobes.pdf|title=Novel nano-organisms from Australian sandstones|work= [[American Mineralogist]]| volume=83|pages=1541–1550|year=1998|display-authors=etal}}</ref> by Philippa Uwins ''et al.'',<ref>[http://www.microscopy-uk.org.uk/nanobes/nanophil.html Nanobes: About Philippa Uwins and the Discovery Team]</ref> from the [[University of Queensland]], [[Australia]]. They were found growing from rock samples (both full-diameter and sidewall cores) of [[Jurassic]] and [[Triassic]] sandstones, originally retrieved from an unspecified number of [[oil exploration]] wells off Australia's west coast. Depths of retrieval were between {{convert|3400|m|mi|1}} and {{convert|5100|m|mi|1}} below the sea bed. While Uwins ''et al.'' present assertions against it, they do not exclude the possibility that the nanobes are from a surface contaminant, not from the rock units cited.
The smallest are just 20 [[Nanometre|nanometers]] in diameter. Some researchers believe that these structures are [[crystal]] growths, but the staining of these structures with dyes that bind to [[DNA]] might indicate that they are living organisms.<ref>[http://serc.carleton.edu/microbelife/topics/nanobes/index.html "Nanobacteria and Nanobes- Are They Alive?"]</ref> They are similar to the structures found in [[ALH84001]], a [[Mars meteorite]] found in the [[Antarctica|Antarctic]]. Nanobes are similar in size to [[nanobacteria]], which are also structures that have been proposed to be extremely small living organisms. However, these two should not be confused. Nanobacteria are thought to be cellular organisms, while nanobes are hypothesized to be a previously unknown form of life or [[protocell]]s.{{Citation needed|date=March 2014}}
== Claims == {{unsourced section|date=July 2017}}
* It is a living organism (contains [[DNA]] or some analogue, and reproduces). * Has a [[Morphology (biology)|morphology]] similar to [[Actinomycetes]] and [[fungi]]. * Nanobes are about 20 [[Nanometre|nm]] in diameter, which may be too small to contain the basic elements for an organism to exist (DNA, ribosomes, etc.), suggesting that if they grow and reproduce they would need to do so in an unconventional way. * The [[Martian meteorite]] [[ALH84001]], discovered in 1984 in the [[Antarctic]], contained similar tubular structures which some [[astrobiology|astrobiologists]] suggested could be evidence of life at an earlier time on [[Mars]].<ref>{{cite journal |author=McSween, H. Y. |title=Evidence for life in a martian meteorite? |journal=GSA Today |volume=7 |issue=7 |pages=1–7 |year=1997 |pmid=11541665}}</ref>
==Responses==
A review in ''Microbes and Environments''<ref name=Velimirov2001>{{cite journal | author = Velimirov, B. | year = 2001 | title = Nanobacteria, Ultramicrobacteria and Starvation Forms: A Search for the Smallest Metabolizing Bacterium | journal = Microbes and Environments | volume = 16 | issue = 2 | pages = 67–77 | url = https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/jsme2/16/2/16_2_67/_pdf | accessdate = 2008-06-23 | doi = 10.1264/jsme2.2001.67}}</ref> of the various ultra-small forms of proposed life states that the main criticism of nanobes is that they appear too small to contain the biochemical machinery needed to sustain life. The review also states that there is no evidence that nanobes are organisms in themselves and not fragments of larger organisms.
Tony Taylor was one of the authors of the original nanobe paper.<ref name=nanobepaper1998 /> He argues that the conspicuous lack of phosphorus in the X-ray spectroscopy data and the failure to find DNA using various DNA amplification techniques demonstrates that nanobes do not have any DNA or RNA. He also argues that they may have a completely different mechanism for heredity, which would account for many of their unusual chemical and physical properties.
== See also ==
* [[Mycoplasma]]—smallest known bacteria (300 nm) * [[Nanoarchaeum]]—smallest known archaeum (400 nm) * [[Nanobacteria]]—possible lifeforms smaller than bacteria (<200 nm) * [[Pandoravirus]]—one of the largest known viruses (1000 nm) * [[Parvovirus]]—smallest known viruses (18-28 nm) * [[Pithovirus]]—largest known virus (1500 nm) * [[Prion]]—smallest known infectious agent (≈10 nm) * [[Protocell]] * [[Ultramicrobacteria]]—possible dormant forms of larger cells (200 nm)
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.microscopy-uk.org.uk/nanobes/nano35000y.jpg Color photo of a nanobe colony] * [http://www.daviddarling.info/encyclopedia/N/nanobe.html Definition of nanobe] * [http://www.microscopy-uk.org.uk/index.html?http://www.microscopy-uk.org.uk/nanobes/nanobes.html Introduction to nanobes]<!---should probably be incorporated in article and deleted under [[WP:EL]]--> * [http://www.astrobio.net/news/article983.html "Nanobes: A New Form of Life?"] * [http://www.microscopy-uk.org.uk/index.html?http://www.microscopy-uk.org.uk/nanobes/nanoimages.html Nanobe images and links] * [http://www.abc.net.au/7.30/stories/s26212.htm Transcript of 7.30 Report interview of Philippa Uwins] * [http://www7.nationalacademies.org/ssb/nanomenu.html Size Limits of Very Small Microorganisms] Proceedings of a Workshop organized by the [[National Academies of Sciences]] * {{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/01/18/science/scientists-find-smallest-form-of-life-if-it-lives.html?sec=&spon=&pagewanted=1 |title=Scientists Find Smallest Form of Life, if It Lives |publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' |author=William J Broad |date=January 18, 2000}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090614004824/http://nai.nasa.gov/news_stories/news_print.cfm?ID=137 How Small Can Life Be?] on [http://astrobiology.nasa.gov/nai/ NAI news].
[[Category:Microbiology]] [[Category:Hypothetical life forms]]

revision.comment: Coined by Finch; unifying definition
revision.text:
{{Expand Russian|Пренебрежимое старение|date=September 2017}} [[File:Testudo horsfieldii locking into the camera.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Some tortoises show negligible senescence.]] '''Negligible senescence''' is a term coined by [[biogerontology|biogerontologist]] [[Caleb Finch]] to denote organisms that do not exhibit evidence of [[senescence]] (biological aging), such as measurable reductions in their reproductive capability, measurable functional decline, or rising death rates with age.<ref name=FinchLSG>{{cite book |last1=Finch |first1=Caleb |title=Longevity, Senescence and the Genome |date=1994 |publisher=. University of Chicago Press |location=Chicago, IL |pages=206-247 |chapter=Negligible Senescence}}</ref>
There are many examples of species for whose organisms scientists have not detected an increase in mortality rate after maturity.<ref name=FinchLSG/> This may mean that the lifespan of the organism is so long that researchers' subjects have not yet lived up to the time when a measure of the species' longevity can be made. Turtles, for example, were once thought to lack senescence, but more extensive observations have found evidence of decreasing fitness with age.<ref name=":0" />
Study of negligibly senescent animals may provide clues that lead to better understanding of the aging process<ref name=FinchLSG/><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Guerin | first1 = J | year = 2004 | title = Emerging area of aging research: long-lived animals with "negligible senescence" | url = | journal = Ann N Y Acad Sci | volume = 1019 | issue = | pages = 518–20 | doi=10.1196/annals.1297.096 | pmid=15247078}}</ref> and influence [[evolution of aging|theories of aging]]. The phenomenon of negligible senescence in some animals is a traditional argument for attempting to achieve similar negligible senescence in humans by technological means.
There are also organisms{{which|date=January 2017}} that exhibit negative senescence, whereby mortality chronologically decreases as the organism ages, for all or part of the life cycle, in disagreement with the [[Gompertz–Makeham law of mortality]]<ref>{{Cite journal|doi=10.1016/S0262-4079(07)62033-8 |title=Evolution's greatest mistakes |year=2007 |author=Ainsworth, C |journal=New Scientist |volume=195 |pages=36–39 |last2=Lepage |first2=M|issue=2616}}</ref> (see also [[Late-life mortality deceleration]]). Furthermore, there are species that have been observed to regress to a larval state and regrow into adults multiple times, such as ''[[Turritopsis dohrnii]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://8e.devbio.com/preview_article.php?ch=2&id=6 |title=Cheating Death: The Immortal Life Cycle of ''Turritopsis'' |publisher=8e.devbio.com |accessdate=2010-03-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100402085711/http://8e.devbio.com/preview_article.php?ch=2&id=6 |archivedate=2010-04-02 |df= }}</ref>
Recent studies have indicated a connection between phenomena related to negligible senescence and the general stability of an organism's [[genome]], specifically [[transcription (genetics)|transcription]] processes, over its lifetime.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kogan|first1=Valeria|first2=Ivan|last2=Molodtcov|first3=Leonid I.|last3=Menshikov|first4=Robert J.|last4=Shmookler Reis|first5=Peter|last5=Fedichev|title=Stability analysis of a model gene network links aging, stress resistance, and negligible senescence|journal=Scientific Reports|volume=5|year=2015|url=http://www.nature.com/articles/srep13589|doi=10.1038/srep13589|pages=13589|pmid=26316217|pmc=4551969}}</ref>
==In vertebrates== Some fish, such as some varieties of [[sturgeon]] and [[rougheye rockfish]], and some [[tortoise]]s and [[turtle]]s<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Miller | first1 = J | year = 2001 | title = Escaping senescence: demographic data from the three-toed box turtle (Terrapene carolina triunguis)". | url = | journal = Exp Gerontol | volume = 36 | issue = 4–6| pages = 829–32 | doi=10.1016/s0531-5565(00)00243-6}}</ref> are thought to be negligibly senescent, although recent research on turtles has uncovered evidence of senescence in the wild.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Warner|first=Daniel A.|last2=Miller|first2=David A. W.|last3=Bronikowski|first3=Anne M.|last4=Janzen|first4=Fredric J.|date=2016-06-07|title=Decades of field data reveal that turtles senesce in the wild|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/113/23/6502|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|language=en|volume=113|issue=23|pages=6502–6507|doi=10.1073/pnas.1600035113|issn=0027-8424|pmc=4988574|pmid=27140634}}</ref> The age of a captured fish specimen can be measured by examining growth patterns similar to [[tree rings]] on the [[otolith]]s (parts of motion-sensing organs).<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Bennett | first1 = J | year = 1882 | title = Confirmation on longevity in Sebastes diploproa (pisces Scorpaenidae) from 210Pb/226Ra measurements in otoliths | url = | journal = Maritime Biology | volume = 71 | issue = | pages = 209–215 | doi=10.1007/bf00394632}}</ref>
==In plants== In plants, [[aspen]] trees are one example of [[biological immortality]]. Each individual tree can live for 40–150 years above ground, but the [[root]] system of the [[clonal colony]] is long-lived. In some cases, this is for thousands of years, sending up new trunks as the older trunks die off above ground. One such colony in [[Utah]], given the nickname of [[Pando (Quaking Aspen)|"Pando"]], is estimated to be 80,000 years old, making it possibly the [[list of long-living organisms|oldest living colony]] of aspens.<ref>[http://www.nps.gov/brca/naturescience/quakingaspen.htm Quaking Aspen] by the [[Bryce Canyon]] [[National Park Service]].</ref>
The world's oldest known living non-[[Vegetative cloning|clonal]] organism was the [[Methuselah (tree)|Methuselah tree]] of the species ''[[Pinus longaeva]]'' growing high in the [[White Mountains (California)|White Mountains]] of [[Inyo County, California|Inyo County]] in eastern [[California]], aged {{Age as of date|4789|1957|August|5}} years.<ref name=database>{{cite web |url=http://www.conifers.org/pi/Pinus_longaeva.php |title= ''Pinus longaeva'' |accessdate= 2008-06-20 |publisher= Gymnosperm Database|date= March 15, 2007}}</ref> This record was superseded in 2012 by another Great Basin bristlecone pine located in the same region as Methuselah, and was estimated to be 5062 years old. The tree was sampled by Edmund Schulman and dated by Tom Harlan.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.rmtrr.org/oldlist.htm |title=OLDLIST, a database of old trees |last=Brown |first=Peter M |date=2012 |publisher=Rocky Mountain Tree-Ring Research, Inc. |access-date=2017-11-29}}</ref>
==In bacteria== Among [[bacteria]], individual organisms are vulnerable and can easily die, but on the level of the [[Colony (biology)|colony]], bacteria can live indefinitely. The two daughter bacteria resulting from [[cell division]] of a parent bacterium can be regarded as unique individuals or as members of a biologically “immortal” colony.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Chao|first=Lin|author2=Guttman, David S.|title=A Model for Damage Load and Its Implications for the Evolution of Bacterial Aging|journal=PLoS Genetics|date=26 August 2010|volume=6|issue=8|pages=e1001076|doi=10.1371/journal.pgen.1001076|pmid=20865171|pmc=2928801}}</ref> The two daughter cells can be regarded as “rejuvenated” copies of the parent cell because damaged macromolecules have been split between the two cells and diluted.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Rang|first=Camilla U.|author2=Peng, Annie Y. |author3=Chao, Lin |title=Temporal Dynamics of Bacterial Aging and Rejuvenation|journal=Current Biology|date=8 November 2011|volume=21|issue=21|pages=1813–1816|doi=10.1016/j.cub.2011.09.018|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0960982211010207|pmid=22036179}}</ref> See [[asexual reproduction]].
==Maximum life span== Some examples of maximum observed life span of animals thought to be negligibly senescent are: {| class="wikitable" |- | [[Rougheye rockfish]] || 205 years<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Munk | first1 = K | year = 2001 | title = Maximum Ages of Groundfishes in Waters off Alaska and British Columbia and Considerations of Age Determination | url = | journal = Alaska Fishery Research Bulletin | volume = 8 | issue = | page = 1 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Cailliet | first1 = G.M. | last2 = Andrews | first2 = A.H. | last3 = Burton | first3 = E.J. | last4 = Watters | first4 = D.L. | last5 = Kline | first5 = D.E. | last6 = Ferry-Graham | first6 = L.A. | year = 2001 | title = Age determination and validation studies of marine fishes: do deep-dwellers live longer?". | url = | journal = Exp. Gerontol | volume = 36 | issue = | pages = 739–764 | doi=10.1016/s0531-5565(00)00239-4}}</ref> |- | [[Aldabra Giant Tortoise]] || 255 years |- | [[Lobster]]s || 100+ years (presumed)<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/28589278/ |title=140-year-old lobster's tale has a happy ending. |publisher=Associated Press |date=January 10, 2009}}</ref> |- | [[Hydra (genus)|Hydra]]s || Observed to be [[biologically immortal]]<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.biochem.uci.edu/Steele/PDFs/Hydra_senescence_paper.pdf |title=Mortality patterns suggest lack of senescence in hydras |first=Daniel E |last=Martínez |journal=Experimental Gerontology |volume=33 |number=3 |year=1998 |pages=217–225 |doi=10.1016/s0531-5565(97)00113-7 |pmid=9615920}}</ref> |- | [[Sea anemone]]s || 60–80 years (generally)<ref name="Sea Anemone">{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/nature/blueplanet/factfiles/jellies/sea_anemone_bg.shtml|title=Fact Files: Sea anemone|publisher=BBC Science and Nature|accessdate=2009-10-01|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090718221530/http://www.bbc.co.uk/nature/blueplanet/factfiles/jellies/sea_anemone_bg.shtml|archivedate=2009-07-18|df=}}</ref> |- | [[Freshwater pearl mussel]] || 210–250 years<ref>{{cite journal|author=Ziuganov, V., San Miguel, E., Neves, R.J., Longa, A., Fernandez, C., Amaro, R., Beletsky, V., Popkovitch, E., Kaliuzhin, S., Johnson, T.|year=2000|title=Life span variation of the freshwater pearlshell: a model species for testing longevity mechanisms in animals.|journal=Ambio|volume=ХХIX|issue=2|pages=102–105|doi=10.1579/0044-7447-29.2.102|url=http://pinnacle.allenpress.com/doi/pdf/10.1579/0044-7447-29.2.102}}</ref><ref name=" Зюганов В.В.">{{cite journal|title=Арктические долгоживущие и южные короткоживущие моллюски жемчужницы как модель для изучения основ долголетия.|author=Зюганов В.В.|journal=Успехи геронтол.|volume=14|pages=21–31|year=2004}}</ref> |- | [[Ocean quahog|Ocean Quahog clam]] || 507 years<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Munro | first1 = D. | last2 = Blier | first2 = P.U. | year = 2012 | title = The extreme longevity of Arctica islandica is associated with increased peroxidation resistance in mitochondrial membranes | url = | journal = Aging Cell | volume = 11 | issue = 5| pages = 845–55 | doi = 10.1111/j.1474-9726.2012.00847.x }}</ref> |- | [[Greenland Shark]] || 400 years<ref name="PE2016">{{cite web|last1=Pennisi|first1=Elizabeth|title=Greenland Shark May Live 400 Years, Smashing Longevity Record|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2016/08/greenland-shark-may-live-400-years-smashing-longevity-record|publisher=Science Magazine|date=11 August 2016}}</ref> |}
==Cryptobiosis== Some rare organisms, such as [[tardigrade]]s, usually have short lifespans, but are able to survive for thousands of years — and, perhaps, indefinitely — if they enter into the state of [[cryptobiosis]], whereby their [[metabolism]] is reversibly suspended. It is hypothesized by advocates of [[cryonics]] that the human [[central nervous system]] can be similarly put into a state of [[suspended animation]] shortly before [[brain death]] to be revived at a future point in the technological development of humankind when such operation would be possible.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}}
==See also== * [[Biological immortality]] * [[DNA damage theory of aging]] * [[Indefinite lifespan]] * [[Maximum lifespan]] * [[Strategies for Engineered Negligible Senescence]]
==References== {{reflist|26em}}
{{Senescence}} {{Longevity}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Negligible Senescence}} [[Category:Senescence]] [[Category:Biological evolution]] [[Category:Immortality]] [[Category:Negligibly senescent organisms|*]]

revision.comment: sp
revision.text:
'''Paratomy''' is a form of [[asexual reproduction]] in animals where the organism splits in a plane perpendicular to the [[antero-posteriorly|antero-posterior axis]] and the split is preceded by the "pregeneration" of the anterior structures in the posterior portion.The developing organisms have their body axis aligned i.e. they develop in a head to tail fashion.
[[Budding]] can be considered to be similar to paratomy except that the body axes need not be aligned: the new head may grow toward the side or even point backward (e.g. ''[[Convolutriloba retrogemma]]'' an [[acoela|acoel]] flat worm).<ref name=Akesson2001>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1046/j.1463-6395.2001.00084.x| issn = 1463-6395| volume = 82| issue = 3| pages = 231–239| last = Åkesson| first = Bertil|author2=Robert Gschwentner |author3=Jan Hendelberg |author4=Peter Ladurner |author5=Johann Müller |author6=Reinhard Rieger | title = Fission in ''Convolutriloba longifissura'': asexual reproduction in acoelous turbellarians revisited| journal = Acta Zoologica| accessdate = 2011-07-13| date = 2001-12-01| url = http://homepage.uibk.ac.at/~c719135/pdf/Akesson-Gschwentner-2001.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1002/bdrc.20135| issn = 1542-9768| volume = 84| issue = 4| pages = 257–264| last = Egger| first = Bernhard| title = Regeneration: rewarding, but potentially risky| journal = Birth Defects Research. Part C, Embryo Today: Reviews| accessdate = 2011-07-13| date = December 2008| url = http://www.uibk.ac.at/zoology/staff/egger/images/egger-regeneration-review-2008.pdf}}</ref> In animals that undergo fast paratomy a chain of [[zooid]]s packed in a head to tail formation may develop. Many [[oligochete]] annelids,<ref name=Herlant1950>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.2307/1538737| issn = 0006-3185| volume = 99| issue = 2| pages = 173–180| last = Herlant-Meewis| first = Henriette| title = Cyst-Formation in Aeolosoma Hemprichi (Ehr)| journal = Biological Bulletin| date = 1950-10-01| jstor = 1538737}}</ref> [[Acoela|acoelous turbellarian]]s,<ref name=Akesson2001/> echinoderm larvae<ref>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.2307/1542036| issn = 0006-3185| volume = 186| issue = 1| pages = 62–71| last = Jaeckle| first = William B.| title = Multiple Modes of Asexual Reproduction by Tropical and Subtropical Sea Star Larvae: An Unusual Adaptation for Genet Dispersal and Survival| journal = Biological Bulletin| date = 1994-02-01| jstor = 1542036}}</ref> and coelenterates<ref>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.2307/3283338| issn = 0022-3395| volume = 80| issue = 1| pages = 1–22| last = Raikova| first = Ekaterina V.| title = Life Cycle, Cytology, and Morphology of Polypodium hydriforme, a Coelenterate Parasite of the Eggs of Acipenseriform Fishes| journal = The Journal of Parasitology| date = 1994-02-01| jstor = 3283338}}</ref> reproduce by this method.
==See also== *[[Autotomy]] *[[Architomy]]
==External resources== This paper has a detailed description of the changes during paratomy.<ref name=Herlant1950/>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Reproduction]]

revision.comment: Dating maintenance tags: {{Cleanup section}}
revision.text:
{{hatnote|This article is about the 1767 book. For people with this given name, see [[Phaedon (name)]]. For the beetle genus, see [[Phaedon (genus)]].}} {{Infobox book | name = Phaedon | title_orig = Phädon oder über die Unsterblichkeit der Seele | translator = | image = Phaedon.jpg | caption = | author = [[Moses Mendelssohn]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = Germany | language = German | series = | subject = [[Immortality]] | published = 1767 | media_type = Print | pages = | isbn = 978-1141640836 | dewey= | congress= | oclc= | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Phaedon''''' ({{lang-de|Phädon oder über die Unsterblichkeit der Seele}}), published in 1767, is a book by the Jewish [[Age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment]] philosopher [[Moses Mendelssohn]], in which Mendelssohn offers a defense of [[immortality]].<ref name="Goodman">{{cite book |author=Goodman, Lenn E. |editor=Honderich, Ted |title=The Oxford Companion to Philosophy |publisher=Oxford University Press |location=Oxford |year=2005 |isbn=0-19-926479-1 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}}</ref>
==Summary== {{cleanup section||reason=Section is currently based on secondary sources discussing the work. It should be based principally on the book itself|date=June 2018}} ''Phaedon'' is a defense of the simplicity and immortality of the soul.<ref name="Goodman" /><ref name="Popkind">{{cite book |author=Popkin, Richard H. |editor=Audi, Robert |title=The Cambridge Dictionary of Philosophy |publisher=Cambridge University Press |location=Cambridge |year=1999 |isbn=0-521-63722-8 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}}</ref> It is a series of three dialogues, revisiting the Platonic dialogue [[Phaedo]], in which [[Socrates]] argues for the immortality of the soul, in preparation for his own death. Many philosophers, including [[Plotinus]], [[Descartes]], and [[Leibniz]], argue that the soul is simple, and that because simples cannot decompose they must be immortal. In the ''Phaedon'', Mendelssohn addresses gaps in earlier versions of this argument (an argument that [[Kant]] calls ''the Achilles of Rationalist Psychology''). The Phaedon contains an original argument for the simplicity of the soul, and also an original argument that simples cannot suddenly disappear. It contains further original arguments that the soul must retain its rational capacities as long as it exists.
==Reception== Materialistic views were at the time rampant and fashionable, and faith in immortality was at a low ebb. At this favourable juncture appeared Phädon oder über die Unsterblichkeit der Seele (Phaedo or On the Immortality of Souls; 1767). Modelled on [[Plato]]'s dialogue of the same name, Mendelssohn's work possessed some of the charm of its Greek exemplar and impressed the German world with its beauty and lucidity of style. The Phaedon was an immediate success, and besides being one of the most widely read books of its time in German it was speedily translated into several European languages, including English. The author was hailed as the "German Plato," or the "German Socrates"; royal and other aristocratic friends showered attentions on him, and it was said that "no stranger who came to Berlin failed to pay his personal respects to the German Socrates."
[[Immanuel Kant]] criticized Mendelssohn's argument for immortality in the second edition of the ''[[Critique of Pure Reason]]'' (1787), at B413–15. Commentators disagree over whether Kant's criticism is successful. Mendelssohn's arguments have been largely overlooked by contemporary analytic philosophers, but philosophers including [[Bertrand Russell]] and [[E.J. Lowe]] have offered arguments for the simplicity of the soul.
==References==
===Footnotes=== {{reflist|20em}}
===Bibliography=== ;Books {{refbegin}} * {{cite book |author=Goodman, Lenn E. |editor=Honderich, Ted |title=The Oxford Companion to Philosophy |publisher=Oxford University Press |location=Oxford |year=2005 |isbn=0-19-926479-1 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}} * {{cite book |author=Popkin, Richard H. |editor=Audi, Robert |title=The Cambridge Dictionary of Philosophy |publisher=Cambridge University Press |location=Cambridge |year=1999 |isbn=0-521-63722-8 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}} {{refend}}
{{Authority control}} [[Category:1767 books]] [[Category:Immortality]] [[Category:Modern philosophical literature]]
